children.source: NACo Analysis of Bureau of Labor Statistics - Local Area Unemployment Statistics (LAUS)

children.definition: All persons in the civilian noninstitutional population classified as either employed or unemployed.
children.name: Civilian Labor Force Population

children.definition: These are all persons who, during the reference week (the week including the 12th day of the month), (a) did any work as paid employees, worked in their own business or profession or on their own farm, or worked 15 hours or more as unpaid workers in an enterprise operated by a member of their family, or (b) were not working but who had jobs from which they were temporarily absent because of vacation, illness, bad weather, childcare problems, maternity or paternity leave, labor-management dispute job training, or other family or personal reasons, whether or not they were paid for the time off or were seeking other jobs. Each employed person is counted only once, even if he or she holds more than one job.
children.name: Number Employed

children.definition: Included are all persons who had no employment during the reference week, were available for work, except for temporary illness, and had made specific efforts to find employment some time during the 4 week-period ending with the reference week. Persons who were waiting to be recalled to a job from which they had been laid off need not have been looking for work to be classified as unemployed.
children.name: Number Unemployed

children.definition: Number of persons unemployed as a percent of the labor force.
children.name: Unemployment Rate
Labor Force

children.source: NACo Analysis of Moody's Analytics data

children.definition: A comprehensive printable report, individualized for each county economy.
children.name: County Economic Profile

children.definition: Cost-of-living adjusted pay for the county economy reflecting price differences between county economies.
children.name: Adjusted Average County Wage
companions: Adjusted Average County Wage Growth Rate

children.definition: Year-over-year growth rate in the average pay in the county economy, adjusted to reflect cost-of-living differences between county economies and price changes over time.  This research adjusts for the cost-of-living with a price index based on the median gross rent from the American Community Survey (ACS) and for inflation using U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index.
children.name: Adjusted Average County Wage Growth Rate
companions: Adjusted Average County Wage Growth Rate
children.source: NACo analysis of Census Bureau ACS 5-year estimates, U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis and U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics

children.definition: The difference between 2014 and 2015 unemployment rates in a county economy.  Shown in percentage points.  The unemployment rate is the proportion of the civilian labor force that is unemployed in a county economy.  Persons are classified as unemployed if they do not have a job, have actively looked for work in the prior four weeks and are currently available for work.
children.name: Unemployment Rate Change

children.definition: Year-over-year jobs growth rate.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.
children.name: Jobs Growth Rate

children.definition: Year-over-year inflation-adjusted economic output (real GDP) growth rate.  Real GDP is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.
children.name: GDP Growth Rate

children.definition: Year-over-year Median Home Sales Prices growth rate.  Median Home Sales Prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.
children.name: Home Price Growth Rate

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of jobs (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from 1990 to the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy. It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.
children.name: Jobs Growth Rate, Long-term

children.definition: The inflation-adjusted annualized growth rate of GDP (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from 1990 to the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.
children.name: GDP Growth Rate, Long-term

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of median home sales prices (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from 1990 to the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009.  Median home sales prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.
children.name: Home Price Growth Rate, Long-term

children.definition: The difference in the Unemployment Rate from the lowest annual rate between 2002 and 2009 to the highest annual rate recorded after that up to 2015.  Shown in percentage points.  The unemployment rate is the proportion of the civilian labor force that is unemployed in a county economy.  Persons are classified as unemployed if they do not have a job, have actively looked for work in the prior four weeks and are currently available for work.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.
children.name: Unemployment Rate Change, Recession

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of jobs (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009 to the lowest number of jobs recorded after that until 2015.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.
children.name: Jobs Growth Rate, Recession

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of GDP (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009 to the lowest annual GDP recorded after that until 2015.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.
children.name: GDP Growth Rate, Recession

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of median home sales prices (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009 to the lowest home price level recorded after that until 2015.  Median home sales prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.  A county economy that experienced no recession on this indicator will appear with the highest quintile on the map.
children.name: Home Price Growth Rate, Recession

children.definition: The difference in the annual unemployment rate from the highest annual rate since 2002 to the 2015 value.  The unemployment rate is the proportion of the civilian labor force that is unemployed in a county economy.  Persons are classified as unemployed if they do not have a job, have actively looked for work in the prior four weeks and are currently available for work.  A county economy that had no increases in the unemployment rate between 2002 and 2009 will show the change from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.
children.name: Unemployment Rate Change, Recovery

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of jobs (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the trough to the 2015 value.  Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.  A county economy that has not had a recession will show the annualized growth rate from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.
children.name: Jobs Growth Rate, Recovery

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of GDP (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the trough to the 2015 value.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.  A county economy that has not had a recession will show the annualized growth rate from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.
children.name: GDP Growth Rate, Recovery

children.definition: The annualized growth rate of median home sales prices (showing how much an indicator would have grown annually, if it increased at a steady rate) from the trough to the 2015 value.  Median Home Sales Prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.  A county economy that has not had a recession will show the annualized growth rate from 2009 to 2015.  A county economy that has not yet entered recovery on this indicator will appear with the lowest quintile on the map.
children.name: Home Price Growth Rate, Recovery

children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its unemployment rate pre-recession low (the lowest annual rate between 2002 and 2009) by 2015.
children.name: Unemployment Rate Recovered

children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its employment pre-recession peak (the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009) by 2015. Jobs represent the total wage and salary jobs, whether full or part-time, temporary or permanent in a county economy.  It counts the number of jobs, not employed people, for all employers in a county economy, not only for the county government.
children.name: Jobs Recovered

children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its home prices pre-recession peak (the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009) by 2015.  Median home sales prices are median sales prices of existing single-family homes in a county economy.
children.name: Home Prices Recovered

children.definition: It identifies whether the county returned to its real GDP pre-recession peak (the highest annual level between 2002 and 2009) by 2015.  Real county economic output (real GDP) is the total value of goods and services produced by a county economy adjusted for inflation, in this case in 2009 chained dollars.
children.name: GDP Recovered

children.definition: The total number of indicators on which this county economy has recovered by 2015 or has experienced no recession since 2002.  Indicators analyzed: jobs, unemployment rates, economic output (GDP) and median home prices.
children.name: Recovered on # Indicators

children.definition:
Average Real Wages: Average annual pay in a county economy, adjusted for inflation. To compare to productivity, this analysis estimates average real wages in 2009 dollars by adjusting average county wages with the BLS Producer Price Index.
Productivity: The inflation-adjusted economic output (real GDP in 2009 dollars) produced by an average job located in the county.
Average County Wage: Average annual pay of a job with the industries located in a county. These wages reflect salaries, bonuses, the cash value of meals and lodging when supplied, tips and other gratuities, and, in some states, employer contributions to certain deferred compensation plans such as 401(k) plans, and stock options. BLS does not include the following categories in the jobs reporting these wages: self-employed workers, most agricultural workers on small farms, all members of the Armed Forces, elected officials in most states, most employees of railroads, some domestic workers, most student workers at schools and employees of certain small nonprofit organizations.

companions: Number of Endangered and Threatened Species Listings

children.definition: An endangered species is a species in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A threatened species is a species likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A species may be treated as endangered or threatened if it resembles in appearance a species which has been listed under section 4 and enforcement personnel would have difficulty distinguishing between the listed and the unlisted species; if the effect of this difficulty is an additional threat to the listed species; and if such treatment of the unlisted species would improve protection for the listed species. A similarity of appearance listing must be promulgated or formalized by rule.  Such species are not biologically endangered or threatened and are not subject to Section 7 consultation.  In some counties threatened species includes experimental non-essential populations.  Experimental, nonessential populations of endangered species (e.g., red wolf) are treated as threatened species on public land, for consultation purposes, and as species proposed for listing on private land.
children.name: Endangered Species Profiles

children.definition: An endangered species is a species in danger of extinction throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A threatened species is a species likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range.  A species may be treated as endangered or threatened if it resembles in appearance a species which has been listed under section 4 and enforcement personnel would have difficulty distinguishing between the listed and the unlisted species; if the effect of this difficulty is an additional threat to the listed species; and if such treatment of the unlisted species would improve protection for the listed species. A similarity of appearance listing must be promulgated or formalized by rule.  Such species are not biologically endangered or threatened and are not subject to Section 7 consultation.  In some counties threatened species includes experimental non-essential populations.  Experimental, nonessential populations of endangered species (e.g., red wolf) are treated as threatened species on public land, for consultation purposes, and as species proposed for listing on private land.

companions: Statewide Number in Substantial Unemployment Areas

children.definition: Amount of WIOA funding allocated by the U.S. Department of Labor to the state for adult employment and training activities for Program Year (July 1 of program year to June 30 of the following year).
children.name: Statewide Adult WIOA Funding

children.definition: Percent change in the amount of WIOA Adult funding allotted to the state in Program Year 2014 and Program Year 2015.
children.name: Statewide Adult WIOA Growth Rate

children.definition: Average number of unemployed individuals in the state that are in areas of substantial unemployment between July 1, 2013 and June 30, 2014.  An area of substantial unemployment is a contiguous area of counties, cities, towns, townships, other minor civil divisions and/or census tracts that has a combined population of at least 10,000 and an average unemployment rate of at least 6.5 percent. One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.
children.name: Statewide Number in Substantial Unemployment Areas

children.definition: Average number of unemployed in excess of 4.5 percent between July 1, 2013 and June 30, 2014.  The number of excess unemployed is determined by the higher of unemployment in excess of 6.5 percent in areas of substantial unemployment or excess unemployment in all areas.  One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.
children.name: Statewide Number of Excess Unemployed

children.definition: Number of adults between 22 and 72 years (or their family members) who are economically disadvantaged based on a 5 year estimate between 2006 and 2010.  The number of economically disadvantaged adults (or their family members) is determined by the Census poverty level or at 70 percent of the Lower Living Standard Income Level.  One third (1/3) of funding from the Department of Labor is based on the state's relative share of this number.
children.name: Statewide Number of Disadvantaged Adults

children.definition:
Counties are classified into one of the following five categories based on the type of local workforce development board (local WDB) serving the county: State Level, Single County, Multiple Counties, County and City or City, as of October 2015.
  • State Level means a county is in the service area of a state run workforce board that fulfills the responsibilities of a local WDB under the Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act.
  • Single County indicates the local WDB serves only the area of one county.
  • Multiple Counties indicates the local WDB serves the area of two or more counties.
  • County and City means a county and one or more cities, including independent cities, are in the service area of a local WDB.
  • A City local WDB serves only some cities within the county so that the entire county is served by multiple local WDBs.
children.name: Local WDB Service Area
children.source: NACo analysis of U.S. Department of Labor data, 2015

children.name: Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act (WIOA)

children.definition: Federal compensation and pension benefits to veterans resident in the county.  It includes: veterans' compensation for service-connected disabilities; dependency and indemnity compensation for service-connected deaths; veterans' pension for nonservice-connected disabilities; and burial and other benefits to veterans and their survivors.
children.name: Compensation and Pension

children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures on education and vocational rehabilitation and employment.  These expenditures to veterans include automobile and adaptive equipment, specially adapted housing, survivors’ and dependents’ educational assistance (chapter 35), vocational rehabilitation for disabled veterans (chapter 31), post-Vietnam era veterans’ educational assistance (chapter 32), Montgomery G.I.  Bill for selected reserves (chapter 1606), reserve educational assistance program (chapter 1607), Montgomery G.I.  Bill (Chapter 30), and post-9/11 veterans educational assistance (chapter 33).
children.name: Education and Vocational Rehabilitation and Employment

children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures on insurance and indemnities.  These expenditures to veterans consist of VA expenditures for death claims, matured endowments, dividends, cash surrender payments, total disability income provision payments, and total and permanent disability benefits payments.
children.name: Insurance and Indemnities

children.definition: U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs expenditures on medical care, consisting of operating expenses incurred through the provision of healthcare services to veterans. These expenditures include dollars for medical services, medical administration, facility maintenance, educational support, research support, and other overhead items.  Medical care expenditures do not include dollars for construction or other non-medical support.  Medical care expenditures are based on where patients live instead of where care is delivered.
children.name: Medical Care

children.definition: Patients residing in the county who received treatment at a VA health care facility.

children.definition: Core Based Statistical Area type as defined the Office of Management and Budget. The 2000 standards provide that each CBSA must contain at least one urban area of 10,000 or more population. Each metropolitan statistical area must have at least one urbanized area of 50,000 or more inhabitants. Each micropolitan statistical area must have at least one urban cluster of at least 10,000 but less than 50,000 population.
children.name: Level of CBSA

children.definition: Status of counties according to the Office of management and Budget. Under the standards, the county (or counties) in which at least 50 percent of the population resides within urban areas of 10,000 or more population, or that contain at least 5,000 people residing within a single urban area of 10,000 or more population, is identified as a central county. Additional outlying counties are included in the CBSA if they meet specified requirements of commuting to or from the central counties.

children.definition: Number of county residents one year or older living in households within the county.
children.name: Population in Households

children.definition: Number of county residents one year or older living in households in the same house as one year ago.
children.name: Same House as 1 Year Ago

children.definition: Share of county residents one year or older living in households in the same house as one year ago.
children.name: Percent In Same House as 1 Year Ago

children.definition: Number of county residents one year or older living in households that moved within the same county in the past year.
children.name: Moved Within Same County

children.definition: Share of county residents one year or older living in households that moved within the same county in the past year.
children.name: Percent Moved Within Same County

children.definition: Number of county residents one year or older living in households that moved from outside the county in the past year.
children.name: Moved From Outside the County

children.definition: Share of county residents one year or older living in households that moved from outside the county in the past year.
children.name: Percent Moved From Outside the County

children.definition: The number of housing units located in the county. A housing unit may be a house, an apartment, a mobile home, a group of rooms or a single room that is occupied (or, if vacant, intended for occupancy) as separate living quarters.
children.name: Number of Housing Units

children.definition: The average number of people occupying a single housing unit in a county. This includes the householder, occupants related to the householder, lodgers, roomers, boarders.
children.name: Average Household Size

children.definition: The number of occupied housing units located in the county. A housing unit is classified as occupied if it is the current place of residence of the person or group of people living in it at the time of interview, or if the occupants are only temporarily absent from the residence for two months or less, that is, away on vacation or a business trip.
children.name: Occupied Housing Units

children.definition: The number of owner-occupied housing units located in the county. A housing unit is owner-occupied if the owner or co-owner lives in the unit.
children.name: Owner-Occupied Housing Units

children.definition: The share of owner-occupied housing units out of the all the housing units located in a county. A housing unit is owner-occupied if the owner or co-owner lives in the unit.
children.name: Percent of Owner-Occupied Housing Units

children.definition: The number of renter-occupied housing units located in the county. All occupied housing units which are not owner-occupied, whether they are rented or occupied without payment of rent.
children.name: Renter-Occupied Housing Units

children.definition: The percentage of renter-occupied housing units located in the county. All occupied housing units which are not owner-occupied, whether they are rented or occupied without payment of rent.
children.name: Percent of Renter-Occupied Housing Units

children.definition: The median estimate of how much owner-occupied houses in a county would sell for if they were for sale. These data exclude mobile homes, houses with a business or medical office, houses on 10 or more acres, and housing units in multi-unit structures.
children.name: Median Home Value

children.definition: The median estimate of gross rent payments in a county. Gross rent is the contract rent plus the estimated average monthly cost of utilities (electricity, gas, and water and sewer) and fuels (oil, coal, kerosene, wood, etc.) if these are paid by the renter (or paid for the renter by someone else).
children.name: Median Gross Rent
Housing Units

children.source: 2016 NACo analysis of Department of Justice Bureau of Justice Statistics, Census of Jails data

children.definition: Total number of persons supervised by the county, including persons confined in a jail facility and not confined (e.g., persons in community based supervision programs run by the jail).
children.name: Total Jail Population

children.definition: The maximum number of beds or inmates assigned to the county's jail facilities by a rating official.
children.name: Rated Jail Capacity

children.definition: The percent of rated capacity occupied by inmates based on the average daily population of the county's jail facilities. This is calculated by dividing the average daily population by rated capacity and multiplying by 100.
children.name: Jail Capacity Percent

children.definition: Number of individuals confined in the county's jail facilities, including individuals in community programs who return to the jail at night, on December 31, 2013.
children.name: Confined Persons

children.definition: Number of persons supervised outside of the county’s jail facilities, including in community based supervision programs such as electronic monitoring, house arrest, community service programs, day reporting and work programs.
children.name: Nonconfined Persons

children.definition: The number of confined persons in the county’s jail facilities that do not hold U.S. citizenship.
children.name: Non US Citizens

children.definition: The number of convicted persons that are released from confinement on weekdays and return to the jail on the weekend to serve their sentence.
children.name: Weekenders

children.definition: The average daily population of the county's jail facilities for January 1, 2013 to December 31, 2013.
children.name: Average Daily Population

children.definition: The percent of rated capacity occupied by inmates based on the average daily population of the county's jail facilities. This is calculated by dividing the average daily population by rated capacity and multiplying by 100.
children.name: Percent of Capacity

children.definition: Indicates whether the county's jail facilities are at or above 100 percent of capacity. Yes indicates that the county's jail facilities are at or above capacity. No indicates the county's jail facilities are below capacity.
children.name: At or Over Capacity
Jails - Supervised Population

children.source: NACo Analysis of Bureau of Justice Statistics - Annual Survey of Jails

Held for Local Jurisdiction outside the State

children.definition: Total inmate population incarcerated or all persons in community-based programs run by jails (e.g., electronic monitoring, house arrest, community service, day reporting, and work programs).
children.name: Total Jail Population

children.definition: Maximum number of beds or inmates allocated to all jail facilities in the county
children.name: Jail Capacity

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for the U.S. Marshals Service.
children.name: Held for US Marshals Service

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for the Federal Bureau of Prisons.
children.name: Held for Federal Bureau of Prisons

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement.
children.name: Held for Immigration & Customs

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for the Bureau of Indian Affairs.
children.name: Held for Bureau of Indian Affairs

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for other federal authorities not listed.
children.name: Held for Other Federal Authorities

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for the state in which the county is located.
children.name: Held for Own State

children.definition: Number of inmates held in the county jail facilities for a state other than the one in which the county is located.
children.name: Held for Other State

children.definition: Number of inmates held in county jail facilities for another local jurisdiction in the state in which the county is located.
children.name: Held for Local Jurisdiction in State

children.definition: Number of inmates held in the county jail facilities for a local jail jurisdictions in a state other than the one in which the county is located.
children.name: Held for Local Jurisdiction outside the State

children.definition: The number of males age 18 or older in the county's jail facilities.
children.name: Adult Males

children.definition: The number of females age 18 or older in the county's jail facilities.
children.name: Adult Females

children.definition: The number of persons, under the age of 18, in the county's jail facilities.
children.name: Total Juveniles

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are convicted.
children.name: Total Convicted

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are unconvicted.
children.name: Total Unconvicted

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are White and not of Hispanic origin.
children.name: White

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are Black or African American and not of Hispanic origin.
children.name: Black or African American

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are Hispanic or Latino.
children.name: Hispanic or Latino

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are Asian and not of Hispanic origin.
children.name: Asian

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are American Indian or Alaskan Native and not of Hispanic origin.
children.name: American Indian or Alaskan Native

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander and not of Hispanic origin.
children.name: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are two or more races and not of Hispanic origin.
children.name: Two or More Races

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities that are other races identified by the county jail's information system.
children.name: Other Inmate Races

children.definition: The number of inmates in the county's jail facilities where their race is not known.
children.name: Race Not Known
Jails - Inmate Demographics

children.source: NACo Analysis of Bureau of Justice Statistics - Annual Survey of Jails

children.definition: Total inmate population incarcerated or all persons in community-based programs run by jails (e.g., electronic monitoring, house arrest, community service, day reporting, and work programs).
children.name: Total Jail Population

children.definition: Maximum number of beds or inmates allocated to all jail facilities in the county
children.name: Jail Capacity

children.definition: Total number of persons housed in jail or persons in community-based programs in the county (e.g. work release, day release, drug/alcohol treatment) who return to jail at night.
children.name: Confined Persons

children.definition: All persons in community-based programs run by jails in the county (e.g., electronic monitoring, house arrest, community service, day reporting, and work programs) but are not housed in the jail.
children.name: Nonconfined Persons

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in a community based electronic monitoring program. Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Electronic Monitoring Program

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in a community based home detention program.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Home Detention

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in a community based community service program.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Community Service

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in a community based day reporting program.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Day Reporting

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in other community based pretrial supervision programs.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Other Pretrial Supervision

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in other community based alternative work programs.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Other Alternative Work Programs

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in community based alcohol or drug treatment programs.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Alcohol/Drug Treatment Programs

children.definition: Number of persons under the county jail's supervision that participate in other programs outside of the county's jail facilities.  Data based on sample of 891 local jails selected and surveyed by the Bureau of Justice Statistics.
children.name: Other Nonconfined Programs
Jails - Community Supervision

children.source: NACo analysis of Department of Justice Bureau of Justice Statistics, Census of Jails, 2013 data

children.definition: Counties are classified into one of three categories to indicate its role in jail operations: Single County, Regional Partner and Combined with State.  Single County indicates the county operates the jail that serves the county.  Regional Partner indicates the county is a partner in the operations of a regional jail that serves two or more jurisdictions.  Combined with State indicates the county does not operate a jail because the state operates a corrections system that unifies county jails and prisons.
children.name: Role in Jail Operations

children.definition: Indicates whether the county operates a jail serving the county.
children.name: Single County Jail

children.definition: Indicates whether the county is the site of a regional jail operation.
children.name: Site of Regional Jail

children.definition: Indicates whether the county is a partner in a regional jail operation.
children.name: Regional Jail Partner

children.definition: Indicates whether the county is in a state where the state operates a unified jail and prison system.
children.name: Combined with State
County Jails

children.source: NACo Research

children.definition: Indicates whether the county has a sheriff that is elected by county constituents
children.name: Elected Sheriff

children.definition: Indicates whether funding for the Sheriff Department's general operations, administrative operations, personnel, field services and any other operating expenses is budgeted by the county
children.name: County Funded Sheriff Department

children.definition: Indicates whether the general operations, functions and responsibilities of the sheriff's office is controlled by the county
children.name: County Operated Sheriff Department

children.definition: Indicates whether the county has a county police department with a Chief of Police in charge of oversight of the department's operations, budget and officers that is elected by county constituents
children.name: Elected Police Chief

children.definition: Indicates whether funding for the police deparment's general operations, administrative operations, personnel, field services, and any other responsibilities of the office is budgeted by the county
children.name: County Funded Police Department

children.definition: Indicates whether the general operations, functions and responsibilities of the police department is controlled by the county
children.name: County Operated Police Department

children.definition: Indicates whether the funding for construction, operation and maintenance of the facility serving the county comes from that county’s budget. The county’s funds may come from taxes collected, fees incurred for various services, including the housing of state, federal or other county’s inmates, commissary sales, and any number of other fees for services.
children.name: County Funded Jails

children.definition: Indicates whether the county funds the judicial salaries, including clerks of court, trail court administrators, court reporters and other court personnel
children.name: County Funded Courts - Salaries

children.definition: Indicates whether the county funds the construction, operating costs and maintenance of the building and property for the court's use.
children.name: County Funded Courts - Buildings/Real Property

children.definition: Indicates whether the county provides funding for general operating expenses of the trial courts
children.name: County Funded Courts - General Operating Expenses

children.definition: Indicates whether the county manages the daily functions and operations of the court and oversees the daily operations of the court administration, processing and judicial functions.
children.name: County Operated Courts

children.definition: Indicates whether the trial court judges for the county level court(s) is elected in an election by county constituents.  Elected judges are often elected to serve a specific term; this does not include the selection process to fill vacancies of judges who do not serve their full term.  Judges can also be appointed by a governing board or authority including a merit committee or judicial nominating commission.
children.name: Elected Judges

children.definition: Indicates whether the clerk of court, who primarily serves as the official record keeper for the courts, is elected as a county position. The responsibilities of the clerk of court vary by state or county statute, but can include maintaining and archiving the records of the court such as marriage licenses, mortgage records and birth certificates. The clerk of court is also be responsible for caseflow management, administering oaths, collecting fines and fees, and jury selection.
children.name: Elected Clerks of Court

children.definition: Indicates whether the official charged with representing the county government in the prosecution of criminal offenses is elected by county constituents. The position can be called many things, including district attorney, county attorney, and county prosecutor. In some states, this responsibility is taken care of on the state level, so there is no such county position.
children.name: Elected District Attorney
Public Safety Structure

children.source: NACo Analysis of Institute of Museum and Library Services - Public Libraries Survey (PLS)
companions: Library Collections - Number of Print Materials

children.definition: Number of central libraries, which are one type of single outlet library (SO) or the library, which is the operational center of a multiple-outlet library (MO or MA). Usually all processing is centralized here and the principal collections are housed here. Synonymous with main library.
children.name: Number of Central Service Outlets

children.definition: Number of branch libraries which are an auxiliary unit of an administrative entity which has at least all of the following:  Separate quarters; An organized collection of library materials; Paid staff; and Regularly scheduled hours for being open to the public.
children.name: Number of Branches

children.definition: Number of bookmobiles in the county. A bookmobile is a traveling branch library. It consists of at least one of the following: A truck or van that carries an organized collection of library materials; paid staff; and regularly scheduled hours (bookmobile stops) for being open to the public.
children.name: Number of Bookmobiles

children.definition: The total number of estimated number of residents in the local service area in all central service outlets in the county
children.name: Population of Local Service Area

children.definition: Number of Full Time Equivalent of librarians. Persons with the title of librarian do paid work that usually requires professional training and skill in the theoretical or scientific aspects of library work, or both, as distinct from its mechanical or clerical aspect.
children.name: Full Time Librarians

children.definition: Number of Full Time Equivalent of librarians and other paid staff
children.name: Total FTE Staff

children.definition: The sum of the annual public service hours for all outlets
children.name: Annual Hours - All Outlets

children.definition: The sum of the Local Government Revenue, State Government Revenue, Federal Government Revenue, and Other Operating Revenue for all central service outlets in the county.
children.name: Total Operating Revenue

children.definition: All local government funds designated by the community, district, or region and available for expenditure by the public library. Do not include the value of any contributed or in-kind services or the value of any gifts and donations, library fines, fees, or grants. Does not include state, federal, and other funds passed through local government for library use. These funds are included with state government revenue or federal government revenue, as appropriate.
children.name: Operating Revenue from Local Government

children.definition: All funds distributed to public libraries by state government for expenditure by the public libraries, except for federal money distributed by the state. This includes funds from such sources as penal fines, license fees, and mineral rights. Note: If operating revenue from consolidated taxes is the result of state legislation, the revenue is reported under state revenue (even though the revenue may be from multiple sources).
children.name: Operating Revenue from State Government

children.definition: All federal government funds distributed to public libraries for expenditure by the public libraries, including federal money distributed by the state.
children.name: Operating Revenue from Federal Government

children.definition: All operating revenue other than that reported under local, state, and federal. For example, this includes monetary gifts and donations received in the current year, interest, library fines, fees for library services, or grants. It does not include the value of any contributed or in-kind services or the value of any non-monetary gifts and donations.
children.name: Other Operating Revenue

children.definition: Salaries and wages for all library staff (including plant operations, security, and maintenance staff) for the fiscal year. Includes salaries and wages before deductions.  Also includes employee benefits outside of salaries and wages paid and accruing to employees regardless of whether the benefits or equivalent cash options are available to all employees. Includes amounts for direct paid employee benefits including Social Security, retirement, medical insurance, life insurance, guaranteed disability income protection, unemployment compensation, workmen’s compensation, tuition, and housing benefits.
children.name: Operating Expenditures Salaries and Benefits

children.definition: The sum of Print Materials Expenditures, Electronic Materials Expenditures, and Other Materials Expenditures.
children.name: Operating Expenditures Library Collections

children.definition: All expenditures other than those reported for Total Staff Expenditures and Total Collection Expenditures.
children.name: Other Operating Expenditures

children.definition: The sum of Total Staff Expenditures, Total Collection Expenditures, and Other Operating Expenditures.
children.name: Total Operating Expenditures

children.definition: The sum of Local Government Capital Revenue, State Government Capital Revenue, Federal Government Capital Revenue, and Other Capital Revenue.
children.name: Total Capital Revenue

children.definition: Total major capital expenditures (the acquisition of or additions to fixed assets). Examples include expenditures for (a) site acquisitions; (b) new buildings; (c) additions to or renovation of library buildings; (d) furnishings, equipment, and initial book stock for new buildings, building additions, or building renovations; (e) library automation systems; (f) new vehicles; and (g) other one-time major projects.
children.name: Total Capital Expenditures

children.definition: Total number includes books including duplicates at all outlets and series back files in print for all outlets.
children.name: Library Collections - Number of Print Materials

children.definition: Total number of Electronic Books (E-books) including duplicates for all outlets.  E-books are digital documents (including those digitized by the library), licensed or not, where searchable text is prevalent, and which can be seen in analogy to a printed book (monograph).
children.name: Library Collections - Number of Electronic Books

children.definition: Total number of audio materials including duplicates for all outlets. These are materials on which sounds (only) are stored (recorded) and that can be reproduced (played back) mechanically, electronically, or both. Include records, audiocassettes, audio cartridges, audio discs (including audio-CD-ROMs), audio-reels, talking books, and other sound recordings, such as web-based or downloaded audiobooks and MP3 files.
children.name: Library Collections - Number of Audio Materials

children.definition: Total number of video materials including duplicates for all outlets. These are materials on which moving pictures are recorded, with or without sound. Electronic playback reproduces pictures, with or without sound, using a television receiver or monitor. Video formats may include tape, DVD, CD-ROM, web-based or downloaded files, etc.
children.name: Library Collections - Number of Video Materials

children.definition: The total number of persons entering the library for whatever purpose during the year.
children.name: Total Annual Visits

children.definition: The total annual circulation of all library materials of all types, including renewals.
children.name: Total Annual Circulation

children.definition: The total number of the library’s Internet computers [personal computers (PCs) and laptops], whether purchased, leased, or donated, used by the general public in the library.
children.name: Number of Computers Available

children.definition: The total number of individuals that have used Internet computers in the library during the last year. If the computer is used for multiple purposes (Internet access, word-processing, OPAC, etc.) and Internet users could not be isolated, all usage is reported.
children.name: Number of Computer Users

children.definition: The total number of licensed databases (including locally mounted or remote, full-text or not) for which temporary or permanent access rights have been acquired through payment by the library, or by formal agreement with the State Library or a cooperative agreement within the state or region. A database is a collection of electronically stored data or unit records (facts, bibliographic data, abstracts, texts) with a common user interface and software for the retrieval and manipulation of the data.
children.name: Number of Licensed Databases

children.definition: Total number of registered borrowers, who are library users who has applied for and received an identification number or card from the public library that has established conditions under which the user may borrow library materials and gain access to other library resources.
children.name: Registered Borrowers

children.definition: Total number of programs offered by the library. A program is any planned event which introduces the group attending to any of the broad range of library services or activities or which directly provides information to participants. Programs may cover use of the library, library services, or library tours. Programs may also provide cultural, recreational, or educational information, often designed to meet a specific social need. Examples of these types of programs include film showings,  lectures, story hours, literacy, English as a second language, citizenship classes, and book discussions.  All programs, whether held on- or off-site, that are sponsored or co-sponsored by the library are included. Programs sponsored by other groups that use library facilities are excluded. If programs are offered as a series, each program in the series is counted. For example, a film series offered once a week for eight weeks is  counted as eight programs. Library activities delivered on a one-to-one basis, rather than to a group, are excluded such as one-to-one literacy tutoring, services to homebound, resume writing assistance, homework assistance, and mentoring activities.
children.name: Total Programs
Libraries

children.source: Americans for the Arts Creative Industries

children.definition: The number of businesses involved in the creation or distribution of the arts—ranging from nonprofit museums, symphonies, and theaters to for-profit film, architecture, and design companies.
children.name: Arts Businesses

children.definition: The number of employees of businesses involved in the creation or distribution of the arts—ranging from nonprofit museums, symphonies, and theaters to for-profit film, architecture, and design companies.
children.name: Arts Employees

children.definition: The number of businesses involved in the creation or distribution of the arts—ranging from nonprofit museums, symphonies, and theaters to for-profit film, architecture, and design companies per 10,000 people.
children.name: Arts Businesses per 10,000 people

children.definition: The number of employees of businesses involved in the creation or distribution of the arts—ranging from nonprofit museums, symphonies, and theaters to for-profit film, architecture, and design companies per 10,000 people.

children.definition: State gas tax rates (fixed or variable), as of May 2015. Gas taxes can be imposed at a fixed rate per gallon (cents per gallon) or as a variable rate tax that is tied to inflation, often as a percentage of the price of gasoline.  Fixed rate gas taxes are not tied to inflation and are only  changed when lawmakers vote to change them.
children.name: State Gas Tax Type
children.source: NACo analysis and update of 2011 Institute for Taxation and Economic Policy (ITEP) data

children.definition: State excise tax on gasoline, as of April 2015. This is a tax imposed on the sale of gasoline.
children.name: State Gas Tax Rate
children.source: NACo Analysis of American Petroleum Institute

children.definition: Number of years since passage of legislation increasing the state gas tax, as of June 2015
children.name: Years Since Last State Gas Tax Increase
children.source: NACo Analysis of various sources, June 2015

children.definition: State imposed limitations on county property tax rates and property assessment, as of February 2014.  These limitations include property tax rate limits, assessment limits, limits on property tax revenue (levy) increases, expenditure limits, property tax freezes.
children.name: State Limits on Property Tax
children.source: NACo update of National Conference of State Legislatures, A Guide to Property Taxes: Property Tax Relief, 2009; February 2014

children.definition: States allowing counties to collect local option gas taxes, as of February 2014. Local option gas tax is a tax collected by a local government on the sale of gasoline within their jurisdiction, if the local government is granted the authority by the state. The revenues from this tax are used for transportation purposes. Besides state authority, often the local government needs a local law or voter approval to implement the local option gas tax. To be considered a local option gas tax for these data, the state authority to collect the tax must be granted to counties; statewide and state collected gas taxes that do not require local approval are not considered local gas taxes.
children.name: State Authorized Local Gas Tax
children.source: NACo analysis of various sources, February 2014

children.definition: County local option sales taxes for transportation, as of February 2014. Local option sales tax is a tax collected by a local government on the sale of any taxable goods within its jurisdiction, if the local government is granted the authority by the state. Besides state authority, often the local government needs a local law or voter approval to implement the local option sales tax. To be considered a local option sales tax for these data, the state authority to collect the tax must be granted to counties and the tax revenue used for transportation or for general purposes, including transportation. A local option sales tax differs from a local option gas tax through the tax base; the local gas tax only applies to the sale of gasoline, whereas a local option sales tax applies to the sale of any taxable goods within the county.
children.name: Local Option Sales Tax
children.source: NACo analysis of 2001 Goldman, Corbett and Wachs data
